S1143674.description: Recognize opposite signs of numbers as indicating locations on opposite sides of 0 on the number line; recognize that the opposite of the opposite of a number is the number itself, e.g., -(-3) = 3, and that 0 is its own opposite.

S1143675.subject: Math
S1143675.description: Understand signs of numbers in ordered pairs as indicating locations in quadrants of the coordinate plane; recognize that when two ordered pairs differ only by signs, the locations of the points are related by reflections across one or both axes.

S1143676.subject: Math
S1143676.description: Find and position integers and other rational numbers on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram; find and position pairs of integers and other rational numbers on a coordinate plane.

S11434D7.subject: Math
S11434D7.description: Understand ordering and absolute value of rational numbers.

S1143677.subject: Math
S1143677.description: Interpret statements of inequality as statements about the relative position of two numbers on a number line diagram.
comments: For example, interpret -3 > -7 as a statement that -3 is located to the right of -7 on a number line oriented from left to right.

S1143678.subject: Math
S1143678.description: Write, interpret, and explain statements of order for rational numbers in real-world contexts.
comments: For example, write -3 °C > -7 °C to express the fact that -3 °C is warmer than -7 °C.

S1143679.subject: Math
S1143679.description: Understand the absolute value of a rational number as its distance from 0 on the number line; interpret absolute value as magnitude for a positive or negative quantity in a real-world situation.
comments: For example, for an account balance of -30 dollars, write |-30| = 30 to describe the size of the debt in dollars.

S114367A.subject: Math
S114367A.description: Distinguish comparisons of absolute value from statements about order.
comments: For example, recognize that an account balance less than -30 dollars represents a debt greater than 30 dollars.

S11434D8.subject: Math
S11434D8.description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by graphing points in all four quadrants of the coordinate plane. Include use of coordinates and absolute value to find distances between points with the same first coordinate or the same second coordinate.

S1143506.subject: Math
S1143506.description: Apply and extend previous understandings of operations with fractions to add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational numbers.

S1143511.subject: Math
S1143511.description: Apply and extend previous understandings of addition and subtraction to add and subtract rational numbers; represent addition and subtraction on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram.

S1143670.subject: Math
S1143670.description: Describe situations in which opposite quantities combine to make 0.
comments: For example, a hydrogen atom has 0 charge because its two constituents are oppositely charged.

S1143671.subject: Math
S1143671.description: Understand p + q as the number located a distance |q| from p, in the positive or negative direction depending on whether q is positive or negative. Show that a number and its opposite have a sum of 0 (are additive inverses). Interpret sums of rational numbers by describing real-world contexts.

S1143672.subject: Math
S1143672.description: Understand subtraction of rational numbers as adding the additive inverse, p - q = p + (-q). Show that the distance between two rational numbers on the number line is the absolute value of their difference, and apply this principle in real-world contexts.

S1143673.subject: Math
S1143673.description: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add and subtract rational numbers.

S1143512.subject: Math
S1143512.description: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division and of fractions to multiply and divide rational numbers.

S114366C.subject: Math
S114366C.description: Understand that multiplication is extended from fractions to rational numbers by requiring that operations continue to satisfy the properties of operations, particularly the distributive property, leading to products such as (-1)(-1) = 1 and the rules for multiplying signed numbers. Interpret products of rational numbers by describing real-world contexts.

S114366D.subject: Math
S114366D.description: Understand that integers can be divided, provided that the divisor is not zero, and every quotient of integers (with non-zero divisor) is a rational number. If p and q are integers, then -(p/q) = (-p)/q = p/(-q). Interpret quotients of rational numbers by describing real-world contexts.

S114366E.subject: Math
S114366E.description: Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide rational numbers.

S114366F.subject: Math
S114366F.description: Convert a rational number to a decimal using long division; know that the decimal form of a rational number terminates in 0s or eventually repeats.

S1143513.subject: Math
S1143513.description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving the four operations with rational numbers.
comments: Computations with rational numbers extend the rules for manipulating fractions to complex fractions.

S1143527.subject: Math
S1143527.description: Know that there are numbers that are not rational, and approximate them by rational numbers.

S1143528.subject: Math
S1143528.description: Know that numbers that are not rational are called irrational. Understand informally that every number has a decimal expansion; for rational numbers show that the decimal expansion repeats eventually, and convert a decimal expansion which repeats eventually into a rational number.

S1143529.subject: Math
S1143529.description: Use rational approximations of irrational numbers to compare the size of irrational numbers, locate them approximately on a number line diagram, and estimate the value of expressions (e.g., π²).
comments: For example, by truncating the decimal expansion of √2, show that √2 is between 1 and 2, then between 1.4 and 1.5, and explain how to continue on to get better approximations.

S11434C7.subject: Math
S11434C7.description: Apply and extend previous understandings of arithmetic to algebraic expressions.

S11434D9.subject: Math
S11434D9.description: Write and evaluate numerical expressions involving whole-number exponents.

S11434DA.subject: Math
S11434DA.description: Write, read, and evaluate expressions in which letters stand for numbers.

S1143669.subject: Math
S1143669.description: Write expressions that record operations with numbers and with letters standing for numbers.
comments: For example, express the calculation "Subtract y from 5" as 5 - y.

S114366A.subject: Math
S114366A.description: Identify parts of an expression using mathematical terms (sum, term, product, factor, quotient, coefficient); view one or more parts of an expression as a single entity.
comments: For example, describe the expression 2 (8 + 7) as a product of two factors; view (8 + 7) as both a single entity and a sum of two terms.

S114366B.subject: Math
S114366B.description: Evaluate expressions at specific values of their variables. Include expressions that arise from formulas used in real-world problems. Perform arithmetic operations, including those involving whole-number exponents, in the conventional order when there are no parentheses to specify a particular order (Order of Operations).
comments: For example, use the formulas V = s³ and A = 6 s² to find the volume and surface area of a cube with sides of length s = 1/2.

S11434DB.subject: Math
S11434DB.description: Apply the properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.
comments: For example, apply the distributive property to the expression 3 (2 + x) to produce the equivalent expression 6 + 3x; apply the distributive property to the expression 24x + 18y to produce the equivalent expression 6 (4x + 3y); apply properties of operations to y + y + y to produce the equivalent expression 3y.

S11434DC.subject: Math
S11434DC.description: Identify when two expressions are equivalent (i.e., when the two expressions name the same number regardless of which value is substituted into them).
comments: For example, the expressions y + y + y and 3y are equivalent because they name the same number regardless of which number y stands for.

S11434C8.subject: Math
S11434C8.description: Reason about and solve one-variable equations and inequalities.

S11434DD.subject: Math
S11434DD.description: Understand solving an equation or inequality as a process of answering a question: which values from a specified set, if any, make the equation or inequality true? Use substitution to determine whether a given number in a specified set makes an equation or inequality true.

S11434DE.subject: Math
S11434DE.description: Use variables to represent numbers and write expressions when solving a real-world or mathematical problem; understand that a variable can represent an unknown number, or, depending on the purpose at hand, any number in a specified set.

S11434DF.subject: Math
S11434DF.description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems by writing and solving equations of the form x + p = q and px = q for cases in which p, q and x are all nonnegative rational numbers.

S11434E0.subject: Math
S11434E0.description: Write an inequality of the form x > c or x < c to represent a constraint or condition in a real-world or mathematical problem. Recognize that inequalities of the form x > c or x < c have infinitely many solutions; represent solutions of such inequalities on number line diagrams.

S11434C9.subject: Math
S11434C9.description: Represent and analyze quantitative relationships between dependent and independent variables.

S11434E1.subject: Math
S11434E1.description: Use variables to represent two quantities in a real-world problem that change in relationship to one another; write an equation to express one quantity, thought of as the dependent variable, in terms of the other quantity, thought of as the independent variable. Analyze the relationship between the dependent and independent variables using graphs and tables, and relate these to the equation.
comments: For example, in a problem involving motion at constant speed, list and graph ordered pairs of distances and times, and write the equation d = 65t to represent the relationship between distance and time.

S1143507.subject: Math
S1143507.description: Use properties of operations to generate equivalent expressions.

S1143514.subject: Math
S1143514.description: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients.

S1143515.subject: Math
S1143515.description: Understand that rewriting an expression in different forms in a problem context can shed light on the problem and how the quantities in it are related.
comments: For example, a + 0.05a = 1.05a means that "increase by 5%" is the same as "multiply by 1.05."

S1143508.subject: Math
S1143508.description: Solve real-life and mathematical problems using numerical and algebraic expressions and equations.

S1143516.subject: Math
S1143516.description: Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically. Apply properties of operations to calculate with numbers in any form; convert between forms as appropriate; and assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies.
comments: For example: If a woman making $25 an hour gets a 10% raise, she will make an additional 1/10 of her salary an hour, or $2.50, for a new salary of $27.50. If you want to place a towel bar 9 3/4 inches long in the center of a door that is 27 1/2 inches wide, you will need to place the bar about 9 inches from each edge; this estimate can be used as a check on the exact computation.

S1143517.subject: Math
S1143517.description: Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.

S1143667.subject: Math
S1143667.description: Solve word problems leading to equations of the form px + q = r and p(x + q) = r, where p, q, and r are specific rational numbers. Solve equations of these forms fluently. Compare an algebraic solution to an arithmetic solution, identifying the sequence of the operations used in each approach.
comments: For example, the perimeter of a rectangle is 54 cm. Its length is 6 cm. What is its width?

S1143668.subject: Math
S1143668.description: Solve word problems leading to inequalities of the form px + q > r or px + q < r, where p, q, and r are specific rational numbers. Graph the solution set of the inequality and interpret it in the context of the problem.
comments: For example: As a salesperson, you are paid $50 per week plus $3 per sale. This week you want your pay to be at least $100. Write an inequality for the number of sales you need to make, and describe the solutions.

S114352A.subject: Math
S114352A.description: Work with radicals and integer exponents.

S114352D.subject: Math
S114352D.description: Know and apply the properties of integer exponents to generate equivalent numerical expressions.
comments: For example, 3² × 3<sup>-5</sup> = 3<sup>-3</sup> = 1/3³ = 1/27.

S114352E.subject: Math
S114352E.description: Use square root and cube root symbols to represent solutions to equations of the form x² = p and x³ = p, where p is a positive rational number. Evaluate square roots of small perfect squares and cube roots of small perfect cubes. Know that √2 is irrational.

S114352F.subject: Math
S114352F.description: Use numbers expressed in the form of a single digit times an integer power of 10 to estimate very large or very small quantities, and to express how many times as much one is than the other.
comments: For example, estimate the population of the United States as 3 × 10<sup>8</sup> and the population of the world as 7 × 10<sup>9</sup>, and determine that the world population is more than 20 times larger.

S1143530.subject: Math
S1143530.description: Perform operations with numbers expressed in scientific notation, including problems where both decimal and scientific notation are used. Use scientific notation and choose units of appropriate size for measurements of very large or very small quantities (e.g., use millimeters per year for seafloor spreading). Interpret scientific notation that has been generated by technology.

S114352B.subject: Math
S114352B.description: Understand the connections between proportional relationships, lines, and linear equations.

S1143531.subject: Math
S1143531.description: Graph proportional relationships, interpreting the unit rate as the slope of the graph. Compare two different proportional relationships represented in different ways.
comments: For example, compare a distance-time graph to a distance-time equation to determine which of two moving objects has greater speed.

S1143532.subject: Math
S1143532.description: Use similar triangles to explain why the slope m is the same between any two distinct points on a non-vertical line in the coordinate plane; derive the equation y = mx for a line through the origin and the equation y = mx + b for a line intercepting the vertical axis at b.

S114352C.subject: Math
S114352C.description: Analyze and solve linear equations and pairs of simultaneous linear equations.

S1143533.subject: Math
S1143533.description: Solve linear equations in one variable.

S1143662.subject: Math
S1143662.description: Give examples of linear equations in one variable with one solution, infinitely many solutions, or no solutions. Show which of these possibilities is the case by successively transforming the given equation into simpler forms, until an equivalent equation of the form x = a, a = a, or a = b results (where a and b are different numbers).

S1143663.subject: Math
S1143663.description: Solve linear equations with rational number coefficients, including equations whose solutions require expanding expressions using the distributive property and collecting like terms.

S1143534.subject: Math
S1143534.description: Analyze and solve pairs of simultaneous linear equations.

S1143664.subject: Math
S1143664.description: Understand that solutions to a system of two linear equations in two variables correspond to points of intersection of their graphs, because points of intersection satisfy both equations simultaneously.

S1143665.subject: Math
S1143665.description: Solve systems of two linear equations in two variables algebraically, and estimate solutions by graphing the equations. Solve simple cases by inspection.
comments: For example, 3x + 2y = 5 and 3x + 2y = 6 have no solution because 3x + 2y cannot simultaneously be 5 and 6.

S1143666.subject: Math
S1143666.description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems leading to two linear equations in two variables.
comments: For example, given coordinates for two pairs of points, determine whether the line through the first pair of points intersects the line through the second pair.

S11434E6.subject: Math
S11434E6.description: Recognize a statistical question as one that anticipates variability in the data related to the question and accounts for it in the answers.
comments: For example, "How old am I?" is not a statistical question, but "How old are the students in my school?" is a statistical question because one anticipates variability in students' ages.

S11434E7.subject: Math
S11434E7.description: Understand that a set of data collected to answer a statistical question has a distribution which can be described by its center, spread, and overall shape.

S11434E8.subject: Math
S11434E8.description: Recognize that a measure of center for a numerical data set summarizes all of its values with a single number, while a measure of variation describes how its values vary with a single number.

S11434E9.subject: Math
S11434E9.description: Display numerical data in plots on a number line, including dot plots, histograms, and box plots.

S11434EA.subject: Math
S11434EA.description: Summarize numerical data sets in relation to their context, such as by:

S2373213.subject: Math
S2373213.description: Describing the nature of the attribute under investigation, including how it was measured and its units of measurement.

S2373214.subject: Math
S2373214.description: Giving quantitative measures of center (median and/or mean) and variability (interquartile range and/or mean absolute deviation), as well as describing any overall pattern and any striking deviations from the overall pattern with reference to the context in which the data were gathered.

S2373215.subject: Math
S2373215.description: Relating the choice of measures of center and variability to the shape of the data distribution and the context in which the data were gathered.

S114350B.subject: Math
S114350B.description: Use random sampling to draw inferences about a population.

S114351E.subject: Math
S114351E.description: Understand that statistics can be used to gain information about a population by examining a sample of the population; generalizations about a population from a sample are valid only if the sample is representative of that population. Understand that random sampling tends to produce representative samples and support valid inferences.

S114351F.subject: Math
S114351F.description: Use data from a random sample to draw inferences about a population with an unknown characteristic of interest. Generate multiple samples (or simulated samples) of the same size to gauge the variation in estimates or predictions.
comments: For example, estimate the mean word length in a book by randomly sampling words from the book; predict the winner of a school election based on randomly sampled survey data. Gauge how far off the estimate or prediction might be.

S114350C.subject: Math
S114350C.description: Draw informal comparative inferences about two populations.

S1143520.subject: Math
S1143520.description: Informally assess the degree of visual overlap of two numerical data distributions with similar variabilities, measuring the difference between the centers by expressing it as a multiple of a measure of variability.
comments: For example, the mean height of players on the basketball team is 10 cm greater than the mean height of players on the soccer team, about twice the variability (mean absolute deviation) on either team; on a dot plot, the separation between the two distributions of heights is noticeable.

S1143521.subject: Math
S1143521.description: Use measures of center and measures of variability for numerical data from random samples to draw informal comparative inferences about two populations.
comments: For example, decide whether the words in a chapter of a seventh-grade science book are generally longer than the words in a chapter of a fourth-grade science book.

S114350D.subject: Math
S114350D.description: Investigate chance processes and develop, use, and evaluate probability models.

S1143522.subject: Math
S1143522.description: Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring. Larger numbers indicate greater likelihood. A probability near 0 indicates an unlikely event, a probability around 1/2 indicates an event that is neither unlikely nor likely, and a probability near 1 indicates a likely event.

S1143523.subject: Math
S1143523.description: Approximate the probability of a chance event by collecting data on the chance process that produces it and observing its long-run relative frequency, and predict the approximate relative frequency given the probability.
comments: For example, when rolling a number cube 600 times, predict that a 3 or 6 would be rolled roughly 200 times, but probably not exactly 200 times.

S1143524.subject: Math
S1143524.description: Develop a probability model and use it to find probabilities of events. Compare probabilities from a model to observed frequencies; if the agreement is not good, explain possible sources of the discrepancy.

S114365D.subject: Math
S114365D.description: Develop a uniform probability model by assigning equal probability to all outcomes, and use the model to determine probabilities of events.
comments: For example, if a student is selected at random from a class, find the probability that Jane will be selected and the probability that a girl will be selected.

S114365E.subject: Math
S114365E.description: Develop a probability model (which may not be uniform) by observing frequencies in data generated from a chance process.
comments: For example, find the approximate probability that a spinning penny will land heads up or that a tossed paper cup will land open-end down. Do the outcomes for the spinning penny appear to be equally likely based on the observed frequencies?

S1143525.subject: Math
S1143525.description: Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams, and simulation.

S114365F.subject: Math
S114365F.description: Understand that, just as with simple events, the probability of a compound event is the fraction of outcomes in the sample space for which the compound event occurs.

S1143660.subject: Math
S1143660.description: Represent sample spaces for compound events using methods such as organized lists, tables and tree diagrams. For an event described in everyday language (e.g., "rolling double sixes"), identify the outcomes in the sample space which compose the event.

S1143661.subject: Math
S1143661.description: Design and use a simulation to generate frequencies for compound events.
comments: For example, use random digits as a simulation tool to approximate the answer to the question: If 40% of donors have type A blood, what is the probability that it will take at least 4 donors to find one with type A blood?

S1143548.subject: Math
S1143548.description: Investigate patterns of association in bivariate data.

S1143549.subject: Math
S1143549.description: Construct and interpret scatter plots for bivariate measurement data to investigate patterns of association between two quantities. Describe patterns such as clustering, outliers, positive or negative association, linear association, and nonlinear association.

S114354A.subject: Math
S114354A.description: Know that straight lines are widely used to model relationships between two quantitative variables. For scatter plots that suggest a linear association, informally fit a straight line, and informally assess the model fit by judging the closeness of the data points to the line.

S114354B.subject: Math
S114354B.description: Use the equation of a linear model to solve problems in the context of bivariate measurement data, interpreting the slope and intercept.
comments: For example, in a linear model for a biology experiment, interpret a slope of 1.5 cm/hr as meaning that an additional hour of sunlight each day is associated with an additional 1.5 cm in mature plant height.

S114354C.subject: Math
S114354C.description: Understand that patterns of association can also be seen in bivariate categorical data by displaying frequencies and relative frequencies in a two-way table. Construct and interpret a two-way table summarizing data on two categorical variables collected from the same subjects. Use relative frequencies calculated for rows or columns to describe possible association between the two variables.
comments: For example, collect data from students in your class on whether or not they have a curfew on school nights and whether or not they have assigned chores at home. Is there evidence that those who have a curfew also tend to have chores?

S1143537.subject: Math
S1143537.description: Understand that a function is a rule that assigns to each input exactly one output. The graph of a function is the set of ordered pairs consisting of an input and the corresponding output.
comments: Function notation is not required in Grade 8.

S1143538.subject: Math
S1143538.description: Compare properties of two functions each represented in a different way (algebraically, graphically, numerically in tables, or by verbal descriptions).
comments: For example, given a linear function represented by a table of values and a linear function represented by an algebraic expression, determine which function has the greater rate of change.

S1143539.subject: Math
S1143539.description: Interpret the equation y = mx + b as defining a linear function, whose graph is a straight line; give examples of functions that are not linear.
comments: For example, the function A = s² giving the area of a square as a function of its side length is not linear because its graph contains the points (1,1), (2,4) and (3,9), which are not on a straight line.

S1143536.subject: Math
S1143536.description: Use functions to model relationships between quantities.

S114353A.subject: Math
S114353A.description: Construct a function to model a linear relationship between two quantities. Determine the rate of change and initial value of the function from a description of a relationship or from two (x, y) values, including reading these from a table or from a graph. Interpret the rate of change and initial value of a linear function in terms of the situation it models, and in terms of its graph or a table of values.

S114353B.subject: Math
S114353B.description: Describe qualitatively the functional relationship between two quantities by analyzing a graph (e.g., where the function is increasing or decreasing, linear or nonlinear). Sketch a graph that exhibits the qualitative features of a function that has been described verbally.

S1143596.subject: Math
S1143596.description: Extend the properties of exponents to rational exponents.

S114360F.subject: Math
S114360F.description: Explain how the definition of the meaning of rational exponents follows from extending the properties of integer exponents to those values, allowing for a notation for radicals in terms of rational exponents.
comments: For example, we define 5<sup>1/3</sup> to be the cube root of 5 because we want (5<sup>1/3</sup>)³ = 5(<sup>1/3</sup>)³ to hold, so (5<sup>1/3</sup>)³ must equal 5.

S1143610.subject: Math
S1143610.description: Rewrite expressions involving radicals and rational exponents using the properties of exponents.

S1143597.subject: Math
S1143597.description: Use properties of rational and irrational numbers.

S1143611.subject: Math
S1143611.description: Explain why the sum or product of two rational numbers is rational; that the sum of a rational number and an irrational number is irrational; and that the product of a nonzero rational number and an irrational number is irrational.

S1143554.subject: Math
comments: Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

S1143598.subject: Math
S1143598.description: Reason quantitatively and use units to solve problems.

S1143612.subject: Math
S1143612.description: Use units as a way to understand problems and to guide the solution of multi-step problems; choose and interpret units consistently in formulas; choose and interpret the scale and the origin in graphs and data displays.

S1143613.subject: Math
S1143613.description: Define appropriate quantities for the purpose of descriptive modeling.

S1143614.subject: Math
S1143614.description: Choose a level of accuracy appropriate to limitations on measurement when reporting quantities.

S1143599.subject: Math
S1143599.description: Perform arithmetic operations with complex numbers.

S1143615.subject: Math
S1143615.description: Know there is a complex number i such that i² = -1, and every complex number has the form a + bi with a and b real.

S1143616.subject: Math
S1143616.description: Use the relation i² = -1 and the commutative, associative, and distributive properties to add, subtract, and multiply complex numbers.

S1143617.subject: Math
S1143617.description: (+) Find the conjugate of a complex number; use conjugates to find moduli and quotients of complex numbers.

S114359A.subject: Math
S114359A.description: Represent complex numbers and their operations on the complex plane.

S1143618.subject: Math
S1143618.description: (+) Represent complex numbers on the complex plane in rectangular and polar form (including real and imaginary numbers), and explain why the rectangular and polar forms of a given complex number represent the same number.

S1143619.subject: Math
S1143619.description: (+) Represent addition, subtraction, multiplication, and conjugation of complex numbers geometrically on the complex plane; use properties of this representation for computation.
comments: For example, (-1 + √3 i)³ = 8 because (-1 + √3 i) has modulus 2 and argument 120°.

S114361A.subject: Math
S114361A.description: (+) Calculate the distance between numbers in the complex plane as the modulus of the difference, and the midpoint of a segment as the average of the numbers at its endpoints.

S114359B.subject: Math
S114359B.description: Use complex numbers in polynomial identities and equations.

S114361B.subject: Math
S114361B.description: Solve quadratic equations with real coefficients that have complex solutions.

S114361C.subject: Math
S114361C.description: (+) Extend polynomial identities to the complex numbers.
comments: For example, rewrite x² + 4 as (x + 2i)(x - 2i).

S114361D.subject: Math
S114361D.description: (+) Know the Fundamental Theorem of Algebra; show that it is true for quadratic polynomials.

S114359C.subject: Math
S114359C.description: Represent and model with vector quantities.

S114361E.subject: Math
S114361E.description: (+) Recognize vector quantities as having both magnitude and direction. Represent vector quantities by directed line segments, and use appropriate symbols for vectors and their magnitudes (e.g., v, |v|, ||v||, v).

S114361F.subject: Math
S114361F.description: (+) Find the components of a vector by subtracting the coordinates of an initial point from the coordinates of a terminal point.

S1143620.subject: Math
S1143620.description: (+) Solve problems involving velocity and other quantities that can be represented by vectors.

S1143658.subject: Math
S1143658.description: Add vectors end-to-end, component-wise, and by the parallelogram rule. Understand that the magnitude of a sum of two vectors is typically not the sum of the magnitudes.

S1143659.subject: Math
S1143659.description: Given two vectors in magnitude and direction form, determine the magnitude and direction of their sum.

S114365A.subject: Math
S114365A.description: Understand vector subtraction v - w as v + (-w), where -w is the additive inverse of w, with the same magnitude as w and pointing in the opposite direction. Represent vector subtraction graphically by connecting the tips in the appropriate order, and perform vector subtraction component-wise.

S1143622.subject: Math
S1143622.description: (+) Multiply a vector by a scalar.

S114365B.subject: Math
S114365B.description: Represent scalar multiplication graphically by scaling vectors and possibly reversing their direction; perform scalar multiplication component-wise, e.g., as c(v<sub>x</sub>, v<sub>y</sub>) = (cv<sub>x</sub>, cv<sub>y</sub>).

S114365C.subject: Math
S114365C.description: Compute the magnitude of a scalar multiple cv using ||cv|| = |c|v. Compute the direction of cv knowing that when |c|v ? 0, the direction of cv is either along v (for c > 0) or against v (for c < 0).

S114359E.subject: Math
S114359E.description: Perform operations on matrices and use matrices in applications.

S1143623.subject: Math
S1143623.description: (+) Use matrices to represent and manipulate data, e.g., to represent payoffs or incidence relationships in a network.

S1143624.subject: Math
S1143624.description: (+) Multiply matrices by scalars to produce new matrices, e.g., as when all of the payoffs in a game are doubled.

S1143625.subject: Math
S1143625.description: (+) Add, subtract, and multiply matrices of appropriate dimensions.

S1143626.subject: Math
S1143626.description: (+) Understand that, unlike multiplication of numbers, matrix multiplication for square matrices is not a commutative operation, but still satisfies the associative and distributive properties.

S1143627.subject: Math
S1143627.description: (+) Understand that the zero and identity matrices play a role in matrix addition and multiplication similar to the role of 0 and 1 in the real numbers. The determinant of a square matrix is nonzero if and only if the matrix has a multiplicative inverse.

S1143628.subject: Math
S1143628.description: (+) Multiply a vector (regarded as a matrix with one column) by a matrix of suitable dimensions to produce another vector. Work with matrices as transformations of vectors.

S1143629.subject: Math
S1143629.description: (+) Work with 2 × 2 matrices as transformations of the plane, and interpret the absolute value of the determinant in terms of area.

S114362A.subject: Math
S114362A.description: Interpret expressions that represent a quantity in terms of its context <sup>★</sup>
comments: Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

S1143651.subject: Math
S1143651.description: Interpret parts of an expression, such as terms, factors, and coefficients.

S1143652.subject: Math
S1143652.description: Interpret complicated expressions by viewing one or more of their parts as a single entity.
comments: For example, interpret P(1+r)<sup>n</sup> as the product of P and a factor not depending on P.

S114362B.subject: Math
S114362B.description: Use the structure of an expression to identify ways to rewrite it.
comments: For example, see x<sup>4</sup> — y<sup>4</sup> as (x²)² — (y²)², thus recognizing it as a difference of squares that can be factored as (x² — y²)(x² + y²).

S114358C.subject: Math
S114358C.description: Write expressions in equivalent forms to solve problems

S114362C.subject: Math
S114362C.description: Choose and produce an equivalent form of an expression to reveal and explain properties of the quantity represented by the expression.<sup>★</sup>
comments: Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

S1143653.subject: Math
S1143653.description: Factor a quadratic expression to reveal the zeros of the function it defines.

S1143654.subject: Math
S1143654.description: Complete the square in a quadratic expression to reveal the maximum or minimum value of the function it defines.

S1143655.subject: Math
S1143655.description: Use the properties of exponents to transform expressions for exponential functions.
comments: For example the expression 1.15<sup>t</sup> can be rewritten as (1.151/12)<sup>12t</sup>  1.012<sup>12t</sup> to reveal the approximate equivalent monhly interest rate if the annual rate is 15%.

S114362D.subject: Math
S114362D.description: Derive the formula for the sum of a finite geometric series (when the common ratio is not 1), and use the formula to solve problems.<sup>★</sup>
comments: For example, calculate mortgage payments.

Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

S1143558.subject: Math
S1143558.description: Arithmetic with Polynomials and Rational Expressions

S114362E.subject: Math
S114362E.description: Understand that polynomials form a system analogous to the integers, namely, they are closed under the operations of addition, subtraction, and multiplication; add, subtract, and multiply polynomials.

S114358E.subject: Math
S114358E.description: Understand the relationship between zeros and factors of polynomials

S114362F.subject: Math
S114362F.description: Know and apply the Remainder Theorem: For a polynomial p(x) and a number a, the remainder on division by x - a is p(a), so p(a) = 0 if and only if (x - a) is a factor of p(x).

S1143630.subject: Math
S1143630.description: Identify zeros of polynomials when suitable factorizations are available, and use the zeros to construct a rough graph of the function defined by the polynomial.

S114358F.subject: Math
S114358F.description: Use polynomial identities to solve problems

S1143631.subject: Math
S1143631.description: Prove polynomial identities and use them to describe numerical relationships.
comments: For example, the polynomial identity (x² + y²)2 = (x² — y²)² + (2xy)² can be used to generate Pythagorean triples.

S1143632.subject: Math
S1143632.description: (+) Know and apply the Binomial Theorem for the expansion of (x + y)<sup>n</sup> in powers of x and y for a positive integer n, where x and y are any numbers, with coefficients determined for example by Pascal's Triangle.
comments: The Binomial Theorem can be proved by mathematical induction or by a combinatorial argument.

S1143633.subject: Math
S1143633.description: Rewrite simple rational expressions in different forms; write <sup>a(x </sup>/<sub>b(x)</sub> in the form q(x) + <sup>r(x)</sup>/<sub>b(x)</sub>, where a(x), b(x), q(x), and r(x) are polynomials with the degree of r(x) less than the degree of b(x), using inspection, long division, or, for the more complicated examples, a computer algebra system.

S1143634.subject: Math
S1143634.description: (+) Understand that rational expressions form a system analogous to the rational numbers, closed under addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division by a nonzero rational expression; add, subtract, multiply, and divide rational expressions.

S1143559.subject: Math
comments: Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

S1143591.subject: Math
S1143591.description: Create equations that describe numbers or relationships

S1143635.subject: Math
S1143635.description: Create equations and inequalities in one variable and use them to solve problems. Include equations arising from linear and quadratic functions, and simple rational and exponential functions.

S1143636.subject: Math
S1143636.description: Create equations in two or more variables to represent relationships between quantities; graph equations on coordinate axes with labels and scales.

S1143637.subject: Math
S1143637.description: Represent constraints by equations or inequalities, and by systems of equations and/or inequalities, and interpret solutions as viable or nonviable options in a modeling context.
comments: For example, represent inequalities describing nutritional and cost constraints on combinations of different foods.

S1143638.subject: Math
S1143638.description: Rearrange formulas to highlight a quantity of interest, using the same reasoning as in solving equations.
comments: For example, rearrange Ohm's law V = IR to highlight resistance R.

S1143592.subject: Math
S1143592.description: Understand solving equations as a process of reasoning and explain the reasoning

S1143639.subject: Math
S1143639.description: Explain each step in solving a simple equation as following from the equality of numbers asserted at the previous step, starting from the assumption that the original equation has a solution. Construct a viable argument to justify a solution method.

S114363A.subject: Math
S114363A.description: Solve simple rational and radical equations in one variable, and give examples showing how extraneous solutions may arise.

S1143593.subject: Math
S1143593.description: Solve equations and inequalities in one variable

S114363B.subject: Math
S114363B.description: Solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable, including equations with coefficients represented by letters.

S114363C.subject: Math
S114363C.description: Solve quadratic equations in one variable.

S1143656.subject: Math
S1143656.description: Use the method of completing the square to transform any quadratic equation in x into an equation of the form (x - p)² = q that has the same solutions. Derive the quadratic formula from this form.

S1143657.subject: Math
S1143657.description: Solve quadratic equations by inspection (e.g., for x² = 49), taking square roots, completing the square, the quadratic formula and factoring, as appropriate to the initial form of the equation. Recognize when the quadratic formula gives complex solutions and write them as a ± bi for real numbers a and b.

S114363D.subject: Math
S114363D.description: Prove that, given a system of two equations in two variables, replacing one equation by the sum of that equation and a multiple of the other produces a system with the same solutions.

S114363E.subject: Math
S114363E.description: Solve systems of linear equations exactly and approximately (e.g., with graphs), focusing on pairs of linear equations in two variables.

S114363F.subject: Math
S114363F.description: Solve a simple system consisting of a linear equation and a quadratic equation in two variables algebraically and graphically.
comments: For example, find the points of intersection between the line y = -3x and the circle x² + y² = 3.

S1143640.subject: Math
S1143640.description: (+) Represent a system of linear equations as a single matrix equation in a vector variable.

S1143641.subject: Math
S1143641.description: (+) Find the inverse of a matrix if it exists and use it to solve systems of linear equations (using technology for matrices of dimension 3 × 3 or greater).

S1143595.subject: Math
S1143595.description: Represent and solve equations and inequalities graphically

S1143642.subject: Math
S1143642.description: Understand that the graph of an equation in two variables is the set of all its solutions plotted in the coordinate plane, often forming a curve (which could be a line).

S1143643.subject: Math
S1143643.description: Explain why the x-coordinates of the points where the graphs of the equations y = f(x) and y = g(x) intersect are the solutions of the equation f(x) = g(x); find the solutions approximately, e.g., using technology to graph the functions, make tables of values, or find successive approximations. Include cases where f(x) and/or g(x) are linear, polynomial, rational, absolute value, exponential, and logarithmic functions.<sup>★</sup>
comments: Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

S1143644.subject: Math
S1143644.description: Graph the solutions to a linear inequality in two variables as a half-plane (excluding the boundary in the case of a strict inequality), and graph the solution set to a system of linear inequalities in two variables as the intersection of the corresponding half-planes.

S1143581.subject: Math
S1143581.description: Understand the concept of a function and use function notation

S11435E9.subject: Math
S11435E9.description: Understand that a function from one set (called the domain) to another set (called the range) assigns to each element of the domain exactly one element of the range. If f is a function and x is an element of its domain, then f(x) denotes the output of f corresponding to the input x. The graph of f is the graph of the equation y = f(x).

S11435EA.subject: Math
S11435EA.description: Use function notation, evaluate functions for inputs in their domains, and interpret statements that use function notation in terms of a context.

S11435EB.subject: Math
S11435EB.description: Recognize that sequences are functions, sometimes defined recursively, whose domain is a subset of the integers.
comments: For example, the Fibonacci sequence is defined recursively by f(0) = f(1) = 1, f(n+1) = f(n) + f(n-1) for n ≥ 1.

S1143582.subject: Math
S1143582.description: Interpret functions that arise in applications in terms of the context

S11435EC.subject: Math
S11435EC.description: For a function that models a relationship between two quantities, interpret key features of graphs and tables in terms of the quantities, and sketch graphs showing key features given a verbal description of the relationship.<sup>★</sup>
comments: Key features include: intercepts; intervals where the function is increasing, decreasing, positive, or negative; relative maximums and minimums; symmetries; end behavior; and periodicity.

Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

S11435ED.subject: Math
S11435ED.description: Relate the domain of a function to its graph and, where applicable, to the quantitative relationship it describes.<sup>★</sup>
comments: For example, if the function h(n) gives the number of person-hours it takes to assemble n engines in a factory, then the positive integers would be an appropriate domain for the function.

Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

S11435EE.subject: Math
S11435EE.description: Calculate and interpret the average rate of change of a function (presented symbolically or as a table) over a specified interval. Estimate the rate of change from a graph.<sup>★</sup>
comments: Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

S11435EF.subject: Math
S11435EF.description: Graph functions expressed symbolically and show key features of the graph, by hand in simple cases and using technology for more complicated cases.<sup>★</sup>
comments: Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

S114364A.subject: Math
S114364A.description: Graph linear and quadratic functions and show intercepts, maxima, and minima.

S114364B.subject: Math
S114364B.description: Graph square root, cube root, and piecewise-defined functions, including step functions and absolute value functions.

S114364C.subject: Math
S114364C.description: Graph polynomial functions, identifying zeros when suitable factorizations are available, and showing end behavior.

S114364D.subject: Math
S114364D.description: (+) Graph rational functions, identifying zeros and asymptotes when suitable factorizations are available, and showing end behavior.

S114364E.subject: Math
S114364E.description: Graph exponential and logarithmic functions, showing intercepts and end behavior, and trigonometric functions, showing period, midline, and amplitude.

S11435F0.subject: Math
S11435F0.description: Write a function defined by an expression in different but equivalent forms to reveal and explain different properties of the function.

S114364F.subject: Math
S114364F.description: Use the process of factoring and completing the square in a quadratic function to show zeros, extreme values, and symmetry of the graph, and interpret these in terms of a context.

S1143650.subject: Math
S1143650.description: Use the properties of exponents to interpret expressions for exponential functions.
comments: For example, identify percent rate of change in functions such as y = (1.02)<sup>t</sup>, y = (0.97)<sup>t</sup>, y = (1.01 <sup>12t</sup>, y = (1.2)<sup>t/10</sup>, and classify them as representing exponential growth or decay.

S11435F1.subject: Math
S11435F1.description: Compare properties of two functions each represented in a different way (algebraically, graphically, numerically in tables, or by verbal descriptions).
comments: For example, given a graph of one quadratic function and an algebraic expression for another, say which has the larger maximum.

S1143584.subject: Math
S1143584.description: Build a function that models a relationship between two quantities

S11435F2.subject: Math
S11435F2.description: Write a function that describes a relationship between two quantities <sup>★</sup>
comments: Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

S11435F3.subject: Math
S11435F3.description: Determine an explicit expression, a recursive process, or steps for calculation from a context.

S11435F4.subject: Math
S11435F4.description: Combine standard function types using arithmetic operations.
comments: For example, build a function that models the temperature of a cooling body by adding a constant function to a decaying exponential, and relate these functions to the model.

S11435F5.subject: Math
comments: For example, if T(y) is the temperature in the atmosphere as a function of height, and h(t) is the height of a weather balloon as a function of time, then T(h(t)) is the temperature at the location of the weather balloon as a function of time.

S11435F6.subject: Math
S11435F6.description: Write arithmetic and geometric sequences both recursively and with an explicit formula, use them to model situations, and translate between the two forms.<sup>★</sup>
comments: Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

S1143585.subject: Math
S1143585.description: Build new functions from existing functions

S11435F7.subject: Math
S11435F7.description: Identify the effect on the graph of replacing f(x) by f(x) + k, k f(x), f(kx), and f(x + k) for specific values of k (both positive and negative); find the value of k given the graphs. Experiment with cases and illustrate an explanation of the effects on the graph using technology. Include recognizing even and odd functions from their graphs and algebraic expressions for them.

S11435F9.subject: Math
S11435F9.description: Solve an equation of the form f(x) = c for a simple function f that has an inverse and write an expression for the inverse.
comments: For example, f(x) =2 x3 or f(x) = (x+1)/(x—1) for x ? 1.

S11435FA.subject: Math
S11435FA.description: (+) Verify by composition that one function is the inverse of another.

S11435FB.subject: Math
S11435FB.description: (+) Read values of an inverse function from a graph or a table, given that the function has an inverse.

S11435FC.subject: Math
S11435FC.description: (+) Produce an invertible function from a non-invertible function by restricting the domain.

S11435FD.subject: Math
S11435FD.description: (+) Understand the inverse relationship between exponents and logarithms and use this relationship to solve problems involving logarithms and exponents.

S114355D.subject: Math
comments: Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

S1143586.subject: Math
S1143586.description: Construct and compare linear, quadratic, and exponential models and solve problems

S11435FE.subject: Math
S11435FE.description: Distinguish between situations that can be modeled with linear functions and with exponential functions.

S11435FF.subject: Math
S11435FF.description: Prove that linear functions grow by equal differences over equal intervals, and that exponential functions grow by equal factors over equal intervals.

S1143600.subject: Math
S1143600.description: Recognize situations in which one quantity changes at a constant rate per unit interval relative to another.

S1143601.subject: Math
S1143601.description: Recognize situations in which a quantity grows or decays by a constant percent rate per unit interval relative to another.

S1143602.subject: Math
S1143602.description: Construct linear and exponential functions, including arithmetic and geometric sequences, given a graph, a description of a relationship, or two input-output pairs (include reading these from a table).

S1143603.subject: Math
S1143603.description: Observe using graphs and tables that a quantity increasing exponentially eventually exceeds a quantity increasing linearly, quadratically, or (more generally) as a polynomial function.

S1143604.subject: Math
S1143604.description: For exponential models, express as a logarithm the solution to ab<sup>ct</sup> = d where a, c, and d are numbers and the base b is 2, 10, or e; evaluate the logarithm using technology.

S1143587.subject: Math
S1143587.description: Interpret expressions for functions in terms of the situation they model

S1143605.subject: Math
S1143605.description: Interpret the parameters in a linear or exponential function in terms of a context.

S1143588.subject: Math
S1143588.description: Extend the domain of trigonometric functions using the unit circle

S1143606.subject: Math
S1143606.description: Understand radian measure of an angle as the length of the arc on the unit circle subtended by the angle.

S1143607.subject: Math
S1143607.description: Explain how the unit circle in the coordinate plane enables the extension of trigonometric functions to all real numbers, interpreted as radian measures of angles traversed counterclockwise around the unit circle.

S1143608.subject: Math
S1143608.description: (+) Use special triangles to determine geometrically the values of sine, cosine, tangent for π/3, π/4 and π/6, and use the unit circle to express the values of sine, cosine, and tangent for π-x, π+x, and 2π-x in terms of their values for x, where x is any real number.

S1143609.subject: Math
S1143609.description: (+) Use the unit circle to explain symmetry (odd and even) and periodicity of trigonometric functions.

S1143589.subject: Math
S1143589.description: Model periodic phenomena with trigonometric functions

S114360A.subject: Math
S114360A.description: Choose trigonometric functions to model periodic phenomena with specified amplitude, frequency, and midline.<sup>★</sup>
comments: Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

S114360B.subject: Math
S114360B.description: (+) Understand that restricting a trigonometric function to a domain on which it is always increasing or always decreasing allows its inverse to be constructed.

S114360C.subject: Math
S114360C.description: (+) Use inverse functions to solve trigonometric equations that arise in modeling contexts; evaluate the solutions using technology, and interpret them in terms of the context.<sup>★</sup>

S114360D.subject: Math
S114360D.description: Prove the Pythagorean identity sin²(θ) + cos²(θ) = 1 and use it to find sin(θ), cos(θ), or tan(θ) given sin(θ), cos(θ), or tan(θ) and the quadrant of the angle.

S114360E.subject: Math
S114360E.description: (+) Prove the addition and subtraction formulas for sine, cosine, and tangent and use them to solve problems.

S1143572.subject: Math
S1143572.description: Experiment with transformations in the plane

S11435BE.subject: Math
S11435BE.description: Know precise definitions of angle, circle, perpendicular line, parallel line, and line segment, based on the undefined notions of point, line, distance along a line, and distance around a circular arc.

S11435BF.subject: Math
S11435BF.description: Represent transformations in the plane using, e.g., transparencies and geometry software; describe transformations as functions that take points in the plane as inputs and give other points as outputs. Compare transformations that preserve distance and angle to those that do not (e.g., translation versus horizontal stretch).

S11435C0.subject: Math
S11435C0.description: Given a rectangle, parallelogram, trapezoid, or regular polygon, describe the rotations and reflections that carry it onto itself.

S11435C1.subject: Math
S11435C1.description: Develop definitions of rotations, reflections, and translations in terms of angles, circles, perpendicular lines, parallel lines, and line segments.

S11435C2.subject: Math
S11435C2.description: Given a geometric figure and a rotation, reflection, or translation, draw the transformed figure using, e.g., graph paper, tracing paper, or geometry software. Specify a sequence of transformations that will carry a given figure onto another.

S1143573.subject: Math
S1143573.description: Understand congruence in terms of rigid motions

S11435C3.subject: Math
S11435C3.description: Use geometric descriptions of rigid motions to transform figures and to predict the effect of a given rigid motion on a given figure; given two figures, use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to decide if they are congruent.

S11435C4.subject: Math
S11435C4.description: Use the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions to show that two triangles are congruent if and only if corresponding pairs of sides and corresponding pairs of angles are congruent.

S11435C5.subject: Math
S11435C5.description: Explain how the criteria for triangle congruence (ASA, SAS, and SSS) follow from the definition of congruence in terms of rigid motions.

S11435C6.subject: Math
S11435C6.description: Prove theorems about lines and angles.
comments: Theorems include: vertical angles are congruent; when a transversal crosses parallel lines, alternate interior angles are congruent and corresponding angles are congruent; points on a perpendicular bisector of a line segment are exactly those equidistant from the segment's endpoints.

S11435C7.subject: Math
comments: Theorems include: measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°; base angles of isosceles triangles are congruent; the segment joining midpoints of two sides of a triangle is parallel to the third side and half the length; the medians of a triangle meet at a point.

S11435C8.subject: Math
comments: Theorems include: opposite sides are congruent, opposite angles are congruent, the diagonals of a parallelogram bisect each other, and conversely, rectangles are parallelograms with congruent diagonals.

S11435C9.subject: Math
S11435C9.description: Make formal geometric constructions with a variety of tools and methods (compass and straightedge, string, reflective devices, paper folding, dynamic geometric software, etc.). Copying a segment; copying an angle; bisecting a segment; bisecting an angle; constructing perpendicular lines, including the perpendicular bisector of a line segment; and constructing a line parallel to a given line through a point not on the line.

S11435CA.subject: Math
S11435CA.description: Construct an equilateral triangle, a square, and a regular hexagon inscribed in a circle.

S1143576.subject: Math
S1143576.description: Understand similarity in terms of similarity transformations

S11435CB.subject: Math
S11435CB.description: Verify experimentally the properties of dilations given by a center and a scale factor:

S2373216.subject: Math
S2373216.description: A dilation takes a line not passing through the center of the dilation to a parallel line, and leaves a line passing through the center unchanged.

S2373217.subject: Math
S2373217.description: The dilation of a line segment is longer or shorter in the ratio given by the scale factor.

S11435CC.subject: Math
S11435CC.description: Given two figures, use the definition of similarity in terms of similarity transformations to decide if they are similar; explain using similarity transformations the meaning of similarity for triangles as the equality of all corresponding pairs of angles and the proportionality of all corresponding pairs of sides.

S11435CD.subject: Math
S11435CD.description: Use the properties of similarity transformations to establish the AA criterion for two triangles to be similar.

S11435CE.subject: Math
comments: Theorems include: a line parallel to one side of a triangle divides the other two proportionally, and conversely; the Pythagorean Theorem proved using triangle similarity.

S11435CF.subject: Math
S11435CF.description: Use congruence and similarity criteria for triangles to solve problems and to prove relationships in geometric figures.

S1143578.subject: Math
S1143578.description: Define trigonometric ratios and solve problems involving right triangles

S11435D0.subject: Math
S11435D0.description: Understand that by similarity, side ratios in right triangles are properties of the angles in the triangle, leading to definitions of trigonometric ratios for acute angles.

S11435D1.subject: Math
S11435D1.description: Explain and use the relationship between the sine and cosine of complementary angles.

S11435D2.subject: Math
S11435D2.description: Use trigonometric ratios and the Pythagorean Theorem to solve right triangles in applied problems.<sup>★</sup>
comments: Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

S11435D3.subject: Math
S11435D3.description: (+) Derive the formula A = 1/2 ab sin(C) for the area of a triangle by drawing an auxiliary line from a vertex perpendicular to the opposite side.

S11435D4.subject: Math
S11435D4.description: (+) Prove the Laws of Sines and Cosines and use them to solve problems.

S11435D5.subject: Math
S11435D5.description: (+) Understand and apply the Law of Sines and the Law of Cosines to find unknown measurements in right and non-right triangles (e.g., surveying problems, resultant forces).

S114357A.subject: Math
S114357A.description: Understand and apply theorems about circles

S11435D6.subject: Math
S11435D6.description: Prove that all circles are similar.

S11435D7.subject: Math
S11435D7.description: Identify and describe relationships among inscribed angles, radii, and chords.
comments: Include the relationship between central, inscribed, and circumscribed angles; inscribed angles on a diameter are right angles; the radius of a circle is perpendicular to the tangent where the radius intersects the circle.

S11435D8.subject: Math
S11435D8.description: Construct the inscribed and circumscribed circles of a triangle, and prove properties of angles for a quadrilateral inscribed in a circle.

S11435D9.subject: Math
S11435D9.description: (+) Construct a tangent line from a point outside a given circle to the circle.

S114357B.subject: Math
S114357B.description: Find arc lengths and areas of sectors of circles

S11435DA.subject: Math
S11435DA.description: Derive using similarity the fact that the length of the arc intercepted by an angle is proportional to the radius, and define the radian measure of the angle as the constant of proportionality; derive the formula for the area of a sector.

S114357C.subject: Math
S114357C.description: Translate between the geometric description and the equation for a conic section

S11435DB.subject: Math
S11435DB.description: Derive the equation of a circle of given center and radius using the Pythagorean Theorem; complete the square to find the center and radius of a circle given by an equation.

S11435DC.subject: Math
S11435DC.description: Derive the equation of a parabola given a focus and directrix.

S11435DD.subject: Math
S11435DD.description: (+) Derive the equations of ellipses and hyperbolas given the foci, using the fact that the sum or difference of distances from the foci is constant.

S114357D.subject: Math
S114357D.description: Use coordinates to prove simple geometric theorems algebraically

S11435DE.subject: Math
S11435DE.description: Use coordinates to prove simple geometric theorems algebraically.
comments: For example, prove or disprove that a figure defined by four given points in the coordinate plane is a rectangle; prove or disprove that the point (1, √3) lies on the circle centered at the origin and containing the point (0, 2).

S11435DF.subject: Math
S11435DF.description: Prove the slope criteria for parallel and perpendicular lines and use them to solve geometric problems (e.g., find the equation of a line parallel or perpendicular to a given line that passes through a given point).

S11435E0.subject: Math
S11435E0.description: Find the point on a directed line segment between two given points that partitions the segment in a given ratio.

S11435E1.subject: Math
S11435E1.description: Use coordinates to compute perimeters of polygons and areas of triangles and rectangles, e.g., using the distance formula.<sup>★</sup>
comments: Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

S114357E.subject: Math
S114357E.description: Explain volume formulas and use them to solve problems

S11435E2.subject: Math
S11435E2.description: Give an informal argument for the formulas for the circumference of a circle, area of a circle, volume of a cylinder, pyramid, and cone.
comments: Use dissection arguments, Cavalieri's principle, and informal limit arguments.

S11435E3.subject: Math
S11435E3.description: (+) Give an informal argument using Cavalieri's principle for the formulas for the volume of a sphere and other solid figures.

S11435E4.subject: Math
S11435E4.description: Use volume formulas for cylinders, pyramids, cones, and spheres to solve problems.<sup>★</sup>

S114357F.subject: Math
S114357F.description: Visualize relationships between two-dimensional and three-dimensional objects

S11435E5.subject: Math
S11435E5.description: Identify the shapes of two-dimensional cross-sections of three-dimensional objects, and identify three-dimensional objects generated by rotations of two-dimensional objects.

S1143580.subject: Math
S1143580.description: Apply geometric concepts in modeling situations

S11435E6.subject: Math
S11435E6.description: Use geometric shapes, their measures, and their properties to describe objects (e.g., modeling a tree trunk or a human torso as a cylinder).<sup>★</sup>
comments: Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

S11435E7.subject: Math
S11435E7.description: Apply concepts of density based on area and volume in modeling situations (e.g., persons per square mile, BTUs per cubic foot).<sup>★</sup>
comments: Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

S11435E8.subject: Math
S11435E8.description: Apply geometric methods to solve design problems (e.g., designing an object or structure to satisfy physical constraints or minimize cost; working with typographic grid systems based on ratios).<sup>★</sup>

S1143552.subject: Math
comments: Modeling is best interpreted not as a collection of isolated topics but in relation to other standards. Making mathematical models is a Standard for Mathematical Practice, and specific modeling standards appear throughout the high school standards indicated by a star symbol (★). The star symbol sometimes appears on the heading for a group of standards; in that case, it should be understood to apply to all standards in that group.

S1143569.subject: Math
S1143569.description: Summarize, represent, and interpret data on a single count or measurement variable

S114359F.subject: Math
S114359F.description: Represent data with plots on the real number line (dot plots, histograms, and box plots).

S11435A0.subject: Math
S11435A0.description: Use statistics appropriate to the shape of the data distribution to compare center (median, mean) and spread (interquartile range, standard deviation) of two or more different data sets.

S11435A1.subject: Math
S11435A1.description: Interpret differences in shape, center, and spread in the context of the data sets, accounting for possible effects of extreme data points (outliers).

S11435A2.subject: Math
S11435A2.description: Use the mean and standard deviation of a data set to fit it to a normal distribution and to estimate population percentages. Recognize that there are data sets for which such a procedure is not appropriate. Use calculators, spreadsheets, and tables to estimate areas under the normal curve.

S114356A.subject: Math
S114356A.description: Summarize, represent, and interpret data on two categorical and quantitative variables

S11435A3.subject: Math
S11435A3.description: Summarize categorical data for two categories in two-way frequency tables. Interpret relative frequencies in the context of the data (including joint, marginal, and conditional relative frequencies). Recognize possible associations and trends in the data.

S11435A4.subject: Math
S11435A4.description: Represent data on two quantitative variables on a scatter plot, and describe how the variables are related.

S1143645.subject: Math
S1143645.description: Fit a function to the data; use functions fitted to data to solve problems in the context of the data.
comments: Use given functions or choose a function suggested by the context. Emphasize linear, quadratic, and exponential models.

S1143646.subject: Math
S1143646.description: Informally assess the fit of a function by plotting and analyzing residuals.

S1143647.subject: Math
S1143647.description: Fit a linear function for a scatter plot that suggests a linear association.

S11435A5.subject: Math
S11435A5.description: Interpret the slope (rate of change) and the intercept (constant term) of a linear model in the context of the data.

S11435A6.subject: Math
S11435A6.description: Compute (using technology) and interpret the correlation coefficient of a linear fit.

S114356C.subject: Math
S114356C.description: Understand and evaluate random processes underlying statistical experiments

S11435A8.subject: Math
S11435A8.description: Understand statistics as a process for making inferences about population parameters based on a random sample from that population.

S11435A9.subject: Math
S11435A9.description: Decide if a specified model is consistent with results from a given data-generating process, e.g., using simulation.
comments: For example, a model says a spinning coin falls heads up with probability 0.5. Would a result of 5 tails in a row cause you to question the model?

S114356D.subject: Math
S114356D.description: Make inferences and justify conclusions from sample surveys, experiments, and observational studies

S11435AA.subject: Math
S11435AA.description: Recognize the purposes of and differences among sample surveys, experiments, and observational studies; explain how randomization relates to each.

S11435AB.subject: Math
S11435AB.description: Use data from a sample survey to estimate a population mean or proportion; develop a margin of error through the use of simulation models for random sampling.

S11435AC.subject: Math
S11435AC.description: Use data from a randomized experiment to compare two treatments; use simulations to decide if differences between parameters are significant.

S1143567.subject: Math
S1143567.description: Conditional Probability and the Rules of Probability

S114356E.subject: Math
S114356E.description: Understand independence and conditional probability and use them to interpret data

S11435AE.subject: Math
S11435AE.description: Describe events as subsets of a sample space (the set of outcomes) using characteristics (or categories) of the outcomes, or as unions, intersections, or complements of other events ("or," "and," "not").

S11435AF.subject: Math
S11435AF.description: Understand that two events A and B are independent if the probability of A and B occurring together is the product of their probabilities, and use this characterization to determine if they are independent.

S11435B0.subject: Math
S11435B0.description: Understand the conditional probability of A given B as P(A and B)/P(B), and interpret independence of A and B as saying that the conditional probability of A given B is the same as the probability of A, and the conditional probability of B given A is the same as the probability of B.

S11435B1.subject: Math
S11435B1.description: Construct and interpret two-way frequency tables of data when two categories are associated with each object being classified. Use the two-way table as a sample space to decide if events are independent and to approximate conditional probabilities.
comments: For example, collect data from a random sample of students in your school on their favorite subject among math, science, and English. Estimate the probability that a randomly selected student from your school will favor science given that the student is in tenth grade. Do the same for other subjects and compare the results.

S11435B2.subject: Math
S11435B2.description: Recognize and explain the concepts of conditional probability and independence in everyday language and everyday situations.
comments: For example, compare the chance of having lung cancer if you are a smoker with the chance of being a smoker if you have lung cancer.

S114356F.subject: Math
S114356F.description: Use the rules of probability to compute probabilities of compound events in a uniform probability model

S11435B3.subject: Math
S11435B3.description: Find the conditional probability of A given B as the fraction of B's outcomes that also belong to A, and interpret the answer in terms of the model.

S11435B4.subject: Math
S11435B4.description: Apply the Addition Rule, P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B), and interpret the answer in terms of the model.

S11435B5.subject: Math
S11435B5.description: (+) Apply the general Multiplication Rule in a uniform probability model, P(A and B) = P(A)P(B|A) = P(B)P(A|B), and interpret the answer in terms of the model.

S11435B6.subject: Math
S11435B6.description: (+) Use permutations and combinations to compute probabilities of compound events and solve problems.

S1143570.subject: Math
S1143570.description: Calculate expected values and use them to solve problems

S11435B7.subject: Math
S11435B7.description: (+) Define a random variable for a quantity of interest by assigning a numerical value to each event in a sample space; graph the corresponding probability distribution using the same graphical displays as for data distributions.

S11435B8.subject: Math
S11435B8.description: (+) Calculate the expected value of a random variable; interpret it as the mean of the probability distribution.

S11435B9.subject: Math
S11435B9.description: (+) Develop a probability distribution for a random variable defined for a sample space in which theoretical probabilities can be calculated; find the expected value.
comments: For example, find the theoretical probability distribution for the number of correct answers obtained by guessing on all five questions of a multiple-choice test where each question has four choices, and find the expected grade under various grading schemes.

S11435BA.subject: Math
S11435BA.description: (+) Develop a probability distribution for a random variable defined for a sample space in which probabilities are assigned empirically; find the expected value.
comments: For example, find a current data distribution on the number of TV sets per household in the United States, and calculate the expected number of sets per household. How many TV sets would you expect to find in 100 randomly selected households?

S1143571.subject: Math
S1143571.description: Use probability to evaluate outcomes of decisions

S11435BB.subject: Math
S11435BB.description: (+) Weigh the possible outcomes of a decision by assigning probabilities to payoff values and finding expected values.

S1143648.subject: Math
S1143648.description: Find the expected payoff for a game of chance.
comments: For example, find the expected winnings from a state lottery ticket or a game at a fast-food restaurant.

S1143649.subject: Math
S1143649.description: Evaluate and compare strategies on the basis of expected values.
comments: For example, compare a high-deductible versus a low-deductible automobile insurance policy using various, but reasonable, chances of having a minor or a major accident.

S11435BC.subject: Math
S11435BC.description: (+) Use probabilities to make fair decisions (e.g., drawing by lots, using a random number generator).

S11435BD.subject: Math
S11435BD.description: (+) Analyze decisions and strategies using probability concepts (e.g., product testing, medical testing, pulling a hockey goalie at the end of a game).
